title: 111_hr3703
content:
The Act may be cited as the "White House Conference on Autism Act of 2009". The Congress acknowledges that Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD) are rapidly increasing in the U.S., affecting all demographics. The rate of autism has surged from 1 in 10,000 in the 1980s to 1 in 150 currently, indicating an epidemic. New cases are diagnosed every 20 minutes, showing no signs of slowing down. The United States is facing an epidemic of autism, with new cases diagnosed every 20 minutes. More children will be diagnosed with autism this year than with AIDS, diabetes, and cancer combined. The cost of autism to the nation is over $35 billion per year, expected to increase in the next decade. The nation's educational, labor, housing, and medical communities are ill-equipped to handle this life-changing condition. Autism is a life-changing condition that is expected to significantly increase in the next decade. Our nation's educational, labor, housing, and medical communities are ill-equipped to handle individuals with autism. This epidemic could potentially deprive the nation of future talent in various fields. Comprehensive research is crucial for understanding the causes of autism and other developmental disorders. The "Combating Autism Act of 2006" allocated nearly $1 billion for autism research, focusing on environmental factors, treatments, and early identification. Autism receives minimal federal funding compared to other childhood diseases, despite being a pressing societal concern. The "Combating Autism Act of 2006" allocated $1 billion for autism research, including studies on environmental factors, treatments, and early identification. A White House Conference on Autism aims to advance research on cutting-edge treatments and services for autism. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION OF THE CONFERENCE. The President is required to call the White House Conference on Autism by December 31, 2010, to make policy recommendations on combating the autism epidemic in the United States. The Secretaries of Health and Human Services, Education, and Housing and Urban Development will plan and convene the Conference. The Co-chairs, including the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Education, and Housing and Urban Development, will plan and convene the Conference on Autism to find the underlying causes, identify solutions for autistic individuals and families, and engage scientific experts. The Conference on Autism aims to identify causes, provide solutions for autistic individuals and families, engage scientific experts in research, and facilitate a national dialogue on addressing challenges faced by autistic children and their families. The Conference on Autism aims to bring together parents of autistic children and leaders in education and social services to address lifelong challenges, highlight innovative programs, and review existing legislation and programs at all levels. The Conference on Autism aims to review existing legislation and programs at all levels to improve services for autistic individuals and their families. The Conference on Autism aims to review existing legislation and programs at all levels to improve services for autistic individuals and their families. SEC. 4. POLICY COMMITTEE; RELATED COMMITTEES. Established by June 30, 2009, the Policy Committee consists of 17 members appointed by the President and the Speaker of the House, including individuals with experience in addressing the needs of people with autism spectrum disorders in the United States. The Policy Committee consists of 6 members with experience in addressing the needs of people with autism spectrum disorders in the United States. House appointees include 2 members selected by the Speaker of the House of Representatives and 2 members selected by the minority leader. The Policy Committee on Energy and Commerce in the House of Representatives consists of 6 members, with appointees selected by the Speaker and minority leader. Senate appointees are selected by the majority leader after consultation with relevant committees. The Senate's Policy Committee members are appointed by the majority and minority leaders, with input from relevant committees. 50% of the members must come from private industry, the nonprofit sector, or academia, including at least one parent or legal guardian. Special Qualifications for members of the Policy Committee include expertise in autism intervention programs, educational programs for individuals with autism, and representation from private industry, the nonprofit sector, or academia. The Policy Committee members must have expertise in autism intervention programs, educational programs for individuals with autism, and knowledge of programs for unique housing and law enforcement needs of individuals with autism. The Policy Committee members must have expertise in autism intervention programs, educational programs for individuals with autism, unique housing and law enforcement needs, and environmental or toxic exposure related to autism development. The Committee acts by majority vote with a quorum required for conducting business. The Policy Committee, chaired by the Surgeon General, acts by majority vote with a quorum required for conducting business. The Committee must meet within 30 days of the last member selection and focuses on autism development. The Policy Committee, chaired by the Surgeon General, meets to make recommendations and submit proposed agendas for the Conference. Meetings are called by the Cochairs and subsequent meetings by the chairperson. The Policy Committee, chaired by the Surgeon General, meets to make recommendations and submit proposed agendas for the Conference. Recommendations include facilitating timely convening, proposing agenda within 90 days, suggesting delegates, determining delegate numbers, and establishing an executive committee. SEC. 5. CONFERENCE DELEGATES.

The Cochairs will gather delegates from various backgrounds in the field of autism and neurodevelopmental disorders, including government representatives, professionals, laypeople, and members of the public affected by autism spectrum disorders in the United States. In administering this section, the Cochairs shall provide written notice to all members of the Policy Committee of each meeting, request cooperation from other Federal departments, and make a proposed agenda available for public comment. The Cochairs of the Policy Committee will detail personnel, provide a proposed agenda for public comment, offer background materials, and hire additional personnel as needed to implement the provisions of the Act. The Cochairs will hire additional personnel as necessary to implement the provisions of the Act, without following certain regulations. They will also ensure that the proposed agenda is prepared. The Cochairs will ensure that the proposed agenda is published in the Federal Register within 30 days of approval, personnel are appointed without political bias, and recommendations are unbiased. The Conference ensures balanced representation, unbiased recommendations, and access to current data on autism spectrum disorders in the US before convening. Before the Conference is convened, the Cochairs ensure that current statistical data and information on autism spectrum disorders in the United States are readily available to delegates. They may obtain this information through grants or agreements with public agencies or nonprofit organizations. Additionally, the Cochairs are allowed to accept gifts on behalf of the United States. The Cochairs may accept gifts (cash or in kind) on behalf of the United States to carry out the Act, which can be earmarked for specific purposes. They are also required to maintain records. Gifts of cash can be accepted in addition to appropriated amounts to carry out the Act, and may be earmarked for specific purposes. The Cochairs are responsible for maintaining records of the sources, amounts, and uses of gifts accepted, as well as the identity of recipients and the amount of assistance received by each person. The Cochairs are responsible for maintaining records of gifts accepted, including sources, amounts, and uses. The Policy Committee will prepare a preliminary report on the Conference within 100 days of adjournment, to be published in the Federal Register and sent to state CEOs. State CEOs must submit their views on the report within 45 days. A final report, including views and findings of the CEOs, will be prepared within 6 months of adjournment. The Policy Committee will prepare a final report of the Conference within 6 months of adjournment. The report will include views and findings of state CEOs and recommendations for administrative action and legislation to implement the findings. SEC. 8. STATUS REPORTS. The Surgeon General must provide an initial status report within 2 years of the Conference adjournment, documenting the implementation of recommendations. Subsequent status reports must be prepared by the Comptroller General every 5 years until all recommendations are achieved. The Comptroller General must provide subsequent status reports every 5 years after the initial report, documenting the implementation of recommendations until all are achieved. These reports are published in the Federal Register and transmitted to the President and Congress. The term "State" in this Act refers to several entities including States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the Virgin Islands, and the Northern Mariana Islands. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization is granted to appropriate necessary funds for the first fiscal year of the Policy Committee planning the Conference, the following fiscal year, and the fiscal year in which the Conference is held. Any new spending authority or authority to enter into contracts under this Act is limited to the extent and amounts specified. The new spending authority and contract authority under the Act are limited to specified amounts in advance in appropriations Acts. Funds appropriated for the Act and gifts received shall be available for one year after the Conference adjourns. Funds appropriated for the Act and gifts received shall remain available for obligation or expenditure for one year after the Conference adjourns. Unexpended funds after this period shall be returned to the United States Treasury, unless the Conference is not convened before December 31, 2010, in which case a trust fund shall be established. If the Conference is not convened before December 31, 2010, a trust fund shall be established for future use.
